entries.title: New Password Security Settings for Zendesk
entries.body:
Today we are excited to release new functionality that allows you to define password security settings for your help desk. You now have the ability to increase the password security requirements for all the agents and users of your help desk. Some benefits of this feature include:

  • Meet internal compliance and policy requirements
  • Increase the security of your help desk

Existing Customers

Current Zendesk customers don't have to do anything to retain their current security settings. Changing the security level is optional.

How does this feature work?

The password security functionality allows you to specify one global password security setting for all of your agents and end-users. You can choose any of these three options:

  • Low: password must be at least 5 characters (default for existing customers)
  • Medium: password must be at least 6 characters and have alphanumeric complexity, with at least one non-alphanumeric character
  • High: password must be at least 6 characters and have alphanumeric complexity, with at least one non-alphanumeric character. Additionally, passwords will expire after 90 days and new passwords must be different from the previous 5 passwords.

User Experience

When you increase the password security level, all passwords will be set to expire in 5 days since users must change their passwords to comply with the new security level. Users will immediately see an in-app notification to this regard. Admins and agents will also be notified three days before and then on the day that their password is set to expire. Users that fail to update their password within those five days will be prompted to do so the next time they log in to the help desk.

Please note that if your help desk has enabled Remote Authentication or SAML authentication, passwords will not expire since they are not stored in Zendesk. Additionally, if agents manually add a Zendesk password to their account, these passwords will not be expired. 

We've also added a global session timeout to Zendesk so that users who are inactive for two weeks will be logged out, which means there will be no impact to users who are actively using Zendesk.

How Admins Can Change Password Security Level

Assuming that you're logged in as an account admin, navigate to Account -> Security and then click on the Password Policy tab:

entries.title: Scheduled maintenance Saturday April 2nd
entries.body:
Zendesk will have an hour long scheduled outage on Saturday April 2nd. In addition to our usual downtime advisory I wanted to give a little more detail about what happens during these outages and the steps we are taking to make Zendesk more scalable and reliable.

I've just written a blog post: Managing Explosive Growth at Zendesk Ops which describes the current scale of Zendesk and some of the things we have recently done and are currently working on to scale the site. Here I'd like to focus on the first item we're currently working on, sharded database servers.

Zendesk has reached the stage where we are outgrowing a single database server. We long knew that this was inevitable given our growth and we've been planning for it for the last 6 months. What we are doing in this maintenance is changing our configuration and software to add a second primary database server.

This is a relatively complex undertaking; as a multi-tenant application we have a large amount of middleware designed to segregate customers data, much of which assumed that this data all resided on a single server. This year, we began rolling out code changes to enable us to fetch data from multiple servers and combine it into a single front end.

Most of these code changes are now in place and have been running smoothly for several months. However the change to add a second database needs to be co-ordinated across all our servers at once. Thus the need for the maintenance; it is a chance for us to bring the site down entirely, make configuration changes while the site has stopped; test the site is functioning correctly and then bring the site back up again.

To use an imperfect analogy, we can redecorate the train and even repair the engine while it remains in motion, but in order to attach a second locomotive we need to bring it to a complete stop first. We'll have much of the engineering staff available during the maintenance to make sure that this is a smooth process.

We know that as our customers you have high expectations of the quality and reliability of Zendesk. It is by making these changes we continue to stay ahead of demand so we can continue provide high reliability and low response time.

Finally, here are the details of the maintenance:

When is the maintenance?

  • (Pacific Time) Saturday, April 2nd from 10:00 to 11:00 Pacific Daylight Time
  • (GMT+0 Time) Saturday, April 2nd from 17:00 to 18:00 GMT

What about incoming new tickets and replies?

During this time new emails will not be immediately processed, however email that was sent to your help desk during the outage will be processed as soon as the outage concludes.

Will my Zendesk dropbox on my website still work?

No. Because the Zendesk dropbox JavaScript is hosted by Zendesk, the Zendesk dropbox will not load during the planned outage. 

We also strongly recommend you place your Zendesk dropbox JavaScript snippets directly above the </body> tag in your HTML markup, otherwise you may experience page load timeouts. 

What will my customers see when Zendesk is down?

During this maintenance there will be periods when Zendesk is entirely unreachable and requests to the site will time out. We will make every effort to minimize these periods and to direct your customers to our standard maintenance page throughout the rest of the maintenance.

Where can I see system status?

Our system status page contains an icon indicating if Zendesk is currently available. This page also contains a record of all past scheduled maintenance and unscheduled downtime. You can also follow the ZendeskOps Twitter which will track the progress of the maintenance.

As always, thanks for reading and thanks for using Zendesk!

Zendesk Operations

entries.title: Announcing improved analytics with GoodData for Zendesk
entries.body:
Starting today, an improved GoodData for Zendesk project template is available to all Zendesk Plus+ customers and trial accounts.  This new template takes full advantage of Zendesk's new business hours and ticket metrics data to provide even deeper insight into your Zendesk ticket activity.

 

 

The new GoodData for Zendesk project template features the following improvements:

Six new dashboards  

Over 25 reports provide improved insight into ticket backlog trends, ticket creation, ticket resolution, agent performance.

New metrics and new reports

 Gain access to pre-built reports which now allow you to report on the following metrics:

  • Reopens.  The number of times a ticket has moved from Solved to Open or Pending.
  • Agent replies.  The number of public agent comments.
  • Assignee stations.  The number of different agents to which a ticket has been assigned.
  • Group stations.  The number of different groups to which a ticket has been assigned. 
  • First reply time.  The time between ticket creation and the first public comment from an agent.
  • Agent wait time.  The cumulative time a ticket has been in a Pending state (awaiting customer response).
  • Requester wait time.  The cumulative time that a ticket is in a New and Open state.
  • First resolution time.  The time from when a ticket is created to when it is first solved.
  • Full resolution time.  The time from when a ticket is created to when it is solved for the last time.

Report in business hours  

Convert any report to use business hours metrics for first reply time, requester wait time, agent wait time, first resolution time and full resolution time and measure true performance based on your support agents' working hours.

 

Getting Started

To get started, visit GoodData's support forum for details on on how to get started with the new project template.  If you want to use the new project template, you will need to create a new project.  If you already have a highly customized project, you may wish to simply add the new metrics to your existing project.

GoodData provides full documentation on how to create a new Zendesk project containing the new dashboards as well as instructions on how to use the new metrics in your existing GoodData project.

entries.title: Introducing Zendesk for iPad
entries.body:
Zendesk for iPad is here!

We are excited to introduce Zendesk for iPad, the latest addition to our suite of mobile clients.  Zendesk for iPad brings the same capabilities of the Zendesk agent interface to the easy-to-use, multi-touch screen of the iPad.  The app provides the same visibility into Zendesk ticket activity as from the online interface, allowing agents to easily view and manage tickets while on the go.

Stay up-to-date on your latest ticket activity

  • Receive real-time updates about your assigned tickets, a feature exclusive to Zendesk for iPad.  Receive push notifications when the following events occur on your tickets:
    - A new or existing ticket is assigned to you
    - A new comment is added to a ticket assigned to you
    - Priority is increased on a ticket assigned to you

  • Access your dashboard of open Zendesk tickets assigned to you and open tickets in your groups

Manage your complete ticket workflow

  • Access your Zendesk ticket views and view tickets as a list or a table
  • View all ticket fields, tags, comments and events
  • Update and create tickets
  • Attach and view attachments and links in your tickets
  • Apply macros
  • When creating new tickets, easily search for an existing requester or add a new one by email address
  • Bookmark tickets for later reference
  • Reference your recently viewed and created tickets
  • Identify a twicket -- a Zendesk ticket created from Twitter -- and tweet back to the requester publicly or via direct message

Search your Zendesk

  • Find relevant tickets, users and forum posts from a unified search interface
  • Search by ticket ID to easily find any ticket, instantly

Get the app today, free!

Zendesk for iPad is available today on the iTunes App Store as a free universal app.  If you currently use Zendesk for iPhone, you will receive Zendesk for iPad as an update.  Learn more by visiting our partner page and watch the screencast below.

 

Do you have an Android or BlackBerry device?

There's an app for you too.  Zendesk provides mobile apps for all major smartphone platforms.  Get Zendesk for Android or Zendesk for BlackBerry today.

entries.title: Capturing phone data - Best Practices
entries.body:

My question is this:  When we get a phone call now, we are opening a new ticket, with the requester being an internal user, and capturing all of the relevant data that way.  Are others doing this, or is there a better way to capture our clients' experiences?  Just looking for ideas and ways that others are using Zendesk when requests for assistance come in via phone.

 

Thanks,

Mark

entries.title: Zendesk dropbox advanced usage
entries.body:
Below I've detailed a few hidden little extras you're able to do with the Zendesk dropbox. 

Pre-populating Fields

You're able to pre-populate certain fields within the Zendesk dropbox. Add the following fields to the init function.

  • requester_name: "Jake Holman" // Pre-populate the requester's name with any value placed into here.
  • requester_email: "jake@zendesk.com" // Pre-populate the requester's email, note this must be a valid email address
  • request_subject: "I am a custom subject",
          request_description: "I am a custom description",
          closeText: "Close Me!",
          loadingText: "Sit tight, mother fucker."
    request_subject: "I am a custom subject" // Pre-populate the subject
  • request_description: "I am a custom description" // Pre-populate the description (the body of the ticket)
  • closeText: "Close Me!" // Customise the close button
  • loadingText: "Sit tight..." // Customise the loading text

This all comes together to look like this: http://www.pastie.org/private/skkduxjaeylebqazgnwhnq

Using a link and removing the tab

In order to use a link, we just bind the Zendesk dropbox opening event to a link.

<a href="http://www.google.com/" onClick="script: Zenbox.show(); return false;">Open</a>

Now, you may want to remove the tab. To do so, add the following to the init function:

  • hide_tab: true // Hides the tab from being shown

Note: the use of anything here is strictly experimental, while we'll do everything we can to not break any of it in the future, customising any Zendesk code shifts the responsibility of upkeep to you!

entries.title: How-to: forward a support request from your inbox to Zendesk
entries.body:
It occasionally happens that a support request gets emailed directly to you instead of your Zendesk help desk. To get it over into your Zendesk, you can either copy/paste the content into the New Ticket form or forward the email to your support email address. The disadvantage of the latter option is that you yourself will be registered as requester; something you thereafter have to change manually.

But there exists an easier way. Most email clients support some kind of feature to redirect an email, preserving the header information except for the to: field. By redirecting an email from your inbox to your Zendesk help desk email address, your help desk will set the original sender as requester and perform all the expected workflow.

Here's how it's done in selected email clients:

Eudora
Select the message, go to the "Message" menu, choose redirect, fill in the address, and choose send. 

Microsoft Outlook 97
Double-click on the message so it opens in a new window. Click on Tools->Resend This Message. A warning will appear about you not being the original sender of the message. Click Yes. A message window appears. Update the To: field and click on 'Send'. 

Microsoft Outlook 2000
Double-click on the message so it opens in a new window. Click on Actions->Resend This Message. A warning will appear about you not being the original sender of the message. Click Yes. A message window appears. Update the To: field and click on 'Send'. 

Evolution
Select the message. In the "Actions" menu, choose the "Forward" submenu (not "Forward message", the "Forward" submenu). Pick "Redirect", fill in the "To" field, and press "Send". 

Mac Mail
With the email message open or selected, go to Mail's 'Message' menu and select 'Redirect'. If you use this frequently, go to the "View" menu, choose "Customize toolbar", and add a button for "Redirect".. 

If you know how to do it in other clients such as Outlook Express, Gmail web or Thunderbird, let us know by posting a comment in this thread.

Thanks to Qmail-Toaster for collecting this information.

Full disclosure. We know of examples where redirecting for some reason doesn't work. Redirecting is not a Zendesk supported feature per se.

entries.title: SPF Records and Spam Control
entries.body:
If you experience that emails from your Zendesk account tend to end up in spam filters, here's a tip for those of you who do not use the standard reply address (ie. the youraccount.zendesk.com domain in the reply address under Accounts/Mails and domains).

Add an SPF (Sender Policy Framework) record. An SPF record is a DNS TXT record which designates the SMTP servers that are authorized to send emails for your domain.

What you need to do, is to simply include the SPF record used for our primary domain. This means that you will not have to worry about IP address changes and the likes in the future. You do this by adding a DNS TXT entry for your domain with the following value:

v=spf1 include:support.zendesk.com ~all

And that's it. If you send out support emails from support@youraccount.com, then adding the above DNS TXT entry to the youraccount.com domain will do the trick.

Once the recipient email server gets an email and can validate that the email is from a server that's specified under the sender domain, it can rule out  that the email has a forged "from" address.

Read more about SPF here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sender_Policy_Framework and here http://www.openspf.org/

entries.title: Scheduling recurring tickets in Zendesk
entries.body:
You can have Zendesk automatically generate a recurring ticket at various intervals by pairing it with an external application that sends out email reminders. In this example, we'll use http://www.rememberthemilk.com as the external application. "Remember the Milk" is a free online task management service. Once you create a task, you can enable this event to send you a reminder of its occurrence via email. You could then specify the reminder to the email address of your Zendesk because any email sent to your Zendesk domain will automatically create a ticket.

1. Create a account at http://www.rememberthemilk.com

2. Within "Remember the Milk", edit your reminder settings by visiting the "Settings" link and then clicking on the "Reminders" tab.

2a. Check off the box that will send you a reminder "At the time the task is due"

2b. Add your Zendesk email address as one of the reminder destinations under the "I want to be reminded by..." section.

3. Create a task by adding a date and time. You can set this task to reoccur on any interval you wish.


Please note that "Remember the Milk" will need to verify your Zendesk email and will send a verification email to your Zendesk. This may end up in your Suspended tickets, so be sure to check this area when completing the verification.

entries.title: How to Use Incidents
entries.body:
Some ticket type basics,
* Question
A request for service or information (service request)
* Incident
An interruptive event
* Problem
A condition resulting in incidents
* Task
A kind of assignment. Will carry a due date (a.k.a deadline). Related to change tasks.

Let's say that you start getting calls about email isn't working. When the ticket is created log it as an Incident. While trouble shooting the email problem 2 more calls about emails problems. You would log them as incidents. Then you would create a problem such as email not working and go back into the 3 incidents you have created and link them to the problem you have just created. As new tickets come in about problems with emails you select the problem you have created for it.

So you find that the email server had to be rebooted. Once the reboot is complete and the server is working again you solve the problem and all the incidents will also be solved with the problem's last comment.

The basic idea is that problems are root causes and incidents are the resultant symptoms of the problem. The benefit of linking incidents to problems is that when the problem is solved all the incidents are solved and the triggers will fire to notify everyone.

entries.title: Bulk Import
entries.body:
This article is DEPRECATED. See Bulk importing users and organizations. 

About

Bulk import is a tool for importing a lot of data in one go. The functionality is located under the Manage / People where you can click the bulk import link. You can import CSV (Comma Separated Values) data as either a file or raw text.

Preparing import data

The import tool expects the user data to be in well formed CSV format. The easiest way to obtain this, is to have the data in Excel, and then save it as CSV. The following picture shows an example Excel sheet:

Note the first line in the sheet is a header. The header must be present, and is used to map columns in the Excel sheet to attributes in zendesk. Data should be in the UTF-8 character set.

Importing users

Supported columns/attributes

As you saw in the last section, you must specify a header. The header tells zendesk what attributes are to be updated on the user. This section explains what attributes can be set during bulk import.

  • name - mandatory
  • email - mandatory
  • password - in clear text, if you are uncomfortable with this, please look into remote authentication. If you provide a password, users will not be notified about the creation of their account.
  • external_id - do you identify your users by some other id than the email address? If so, use that here
  • details
  • notes
  • phone
  • role - one of "end user", "agent" or "admin"
  • restriction - one of "requested", "organization", "assigned", "groups" or "none". Will be reset to a restriction which is appropriate for the role as e.g. the groups restriction makes no sense for end users
  • organization - if the user is to be member of a specific organization, set the name of that here

Import process

Once you submit a CSV file with some of the above columns, the following steps are taken for each row in that file:

  1. Look up the user by external_id (if given) otherwise email
  2. If there is no such user, create a new user with the specified attributes
  3. If the user exists, and the update option is checked, update the user attributes

 

Importing organizations

Supported columns/attributes

You must specify a header. The header tells zendesk what attributes are to be updated on the organization.

  • name - mandatory
  • notes
  • details
  • default - the default user mapping for the organization
  • shared - shared organization? one of "true" or "false"
  • shared_comments - shared comments for organization? one of "true" or "false", requires that shared setting is also in the import data
  • group - name of the group to map this organization to, if any

Import process

Once you submit a CSV file with some of the above columns, the following steps are taken for each row in that file:

  1. Look up the organization by name
  2. If there is no such organization, create a new organization with the specified attributes
  3. If the organization exists, and the update option is checked, update the organization attributes

entries.title: Suspended Tickets in Detail
entries.body:
Suspended tickets

When an email is received by Zendesk, a series of processing rules are executed. For example, there's a rule to determine to which account this email belongs, and another rule which determines if this is a spam email.

Four things can happen to an email received by Zendesk:

  1. A ticket gets created or updated. This happens in most cases, and does so when a valid email has been received.
  2. A bounce email gets sent back. This happens when  a account has exceeded its limitations.
  3. A suspended ticket gets created. This happens when the email violates a processing rule (more on this below).
  4. A hard reject, email gets silently refused by Zendesk. This only happens in the single case where there's a 99.9% probability of the email being spam.

The interesting part of the ticket processing engine, is item 3 in the above. We run a series of tests and validations to ensure that the inbound email is indeed valid, and if not, we suspend it.

Causes of suspension

We operate with the following causes of suspension:

Detected as spam The email has been determined to be spam with high probability (but less than the 99.9% mentioned above).

Sender domain not on whitelist Your account is configured to only allow emails from a given set of domains, and the sender domain is not within that set.

Submitted by unverified user The user sending the email has not yet clicked the verification link in his welcome email.

Automated response mail Emails sent by auto mailers that have set a header in the mail, telling us that this is an auto generated response email.

Detected as mail loop If a sender exceeds a threshold by sending a large number of emails to your account within a small time frame, the sender address gets blacklisted for an hour, and emails received in this interval become suspended tickets. This will also happen to tickets that are sent from an address equal to your default reply-to address.

Unknown user tried to update existing ticket Someone tried to send an update to an existing ticket without having an account in Zendesk.

End user only allowed to update their own tickets An end user tried to update a ticket which was not submitted by himself. This typically happens when an end-user has multiple email addresses and replies to a notification from an address other than the one registered on the ticket either as assignee or cc.

Automated response mail, delivery failed If an email sent from your account got rejected somewhere in the email delivery mechanism.

Automated response mail, out of office An email sent from your account to an end user resulted in an "out of office" or "vacation" email, suspend this notice.

Detected email as being from a system user When the sender is another mail server (typically mail-daemon@something or postmaster@something) odds are that this mail was not intended to become a ticket.

Permission denied for unknown email submitter Accounts that are configured to not accept email from anyone will get this cause of suspension when the sender does not exist in Zendesk.

User must sign up to submit email, user notified Accounts that are configured to accept email from anyone will get this cause of suspension. Note, a verification link has been sent to the user, so most likely, you should not handle this type of suspension manually.

Got an itch?

We strive to make the Zendesk email integration absolutely world class. But as you probably know from your own private inbox, spam and email abuse is tough challenge. If a sender of an email is not polite and does not set correct information in the email, we're left to determine whether en email is valid purely by evaluating its structure and content.

If there's something you would like handled (or handled differently) in the email processing system, don't hesitate to let us know.

entries.title: Smart Searching
entries.body:
Searching in Zendesk works as you would expect; you enter words you wish to search for, and Zendesk returns all items that contain ALL of the words entered. The result set is ordered intelligently, e.g. tag matches are ranked higher than content matches. Items included in the search are users, groups, organizations, tickets and topics.

In addition, Smart Search offers various operators and property keywords. With Smart Search you can combine your free text search queries with smart queries and perform searches such as HP driver assignee:me, priority>normal and email:company.com. Embracing Smart Search will really speed up your day-to-day work routines.

Property keywords

There are some property keywords that you can use for customized search results. Keywords should be entered after the query and follow this format: keyword:value keyword:value or keyword:value keyword:”value1 value2” as any values with spaces must be surrounded by quotes.

  • requester, submitter or assignee – This lets you search for tickets that are requested, submitted or assigned to/by a specific person. You can enter the person’s full name, or just the beginning of it. Also, you can use “me” as a special keyword to associate yourself or use “none” to designate no person. Examples: submitter:”John Smith”, submitter:john, requester:me, assignee:none
  • status, priority and ticket_type – searches for tickets with specific property values. Examples status:pending, priority
  • created, updated, solved and due_date – searches for tickets created, updated, solved or with due_date before, after or equals than the given date. Examples: created<2010-01-10, updated>2010-01-10, solved:2010-01-10, due_date>2010-01-10
  • group – lets you limit the search to tickets assigned to specific groups. Example: group:software
  • organization - limit by ticket organization, .e.g. organization:wooldsworth.
  • tags – Searches ticket and topics by tag. Examples tags:printer
  • type - Limits the search by item type. E.g. type:user

entries.title: Inborn Ticket Rules
entries.body:
Some business rules in Zendesk are inborn, meaning that they cannot be reconfigured and makes part of a help desk's modus operandi: 

  • When a ticket is assigned to an agent, its status changes automatically to Open.
  • Once a ticket's status has been changed from New, it can never be set back to New.
  • If a ticket's status is set to Pending or Solved, and requester performs an update, status is changed back to Open.
  • A ticket's status cannot be set to solved without an assignee.
  • Once a ticket has been assigned to a group, group cannot be reset.
  • Once a ticket has been assigned to an agent in a group, assignee cannot be reset within that group.
  • Once a priority has been set, priority cannot be reset.
  • When a ticket has been set to closed, it can never be updated, it can only be deleted.
  • If there's only one group in the help desk, all tickets are automatically assigned to that group.
  • If there's only one agent in a group, all tickets to that group are automatically assigned to that agent.
  • If a ticket is assigned to an agent, but not a group, the ticket will automatically be assigned to the first group the agent is a member of.

entries.title: Run your own custom ticket score calculation
entries.body:
Zendesk provides a method for calculating the score of a ticket. It mostly depends on how qualified a ticket is - ie. if fields such as priority or assignee have been set. The more fields are set the lower the score is.

We wanted to run a different method so that aspects like the age of the ticket and the importance of the customer are factored in. Unfortunately Zendesk provides no built-in way to do this but using the wonderful REST API it was quite straightorward to implement.

First you will need to create an API endpoint which will perform the calculation of the score. I used the PHP Wrapper for the Zendesk API: http://code.google.com/p/zendesk-php-lib/. Then setup a Zendesk Trigger to call the target when a Ticket is created or updated. Finally create a custom ticket field for numeric values to hold the ticket score and a view that orders tickets by custom score.

The API endpoint in our case looks roughly like this:

  /* how old a ticket may be before it is given the MAX_SCORE for the age component */
  define('MAX_AGE', 14);
  /* the maximum score for each component (age, customer, priority etc.) */
  define('MAX_SCORE', 10);
  /* ticket that can not be assigned to a customer receive a healthy default score so they don't
   * get lost */
  define('DEFAULT_SCORE', 2 * MAX_SCORE);
  /* the maximum priority a ticket can have in Zendesk (4 = urgent) */
  define('MAX_TICKET_PRIORITY', 4);
  /* how many tickets Zendesk returns per API call; this is hardcoded in Zendesk */
  define('TICKETS_PER_PAGE', 15);

  $zd = new Zendesk(...);

  /* get the ticket */
  $ticket_id = $_GET['value'];
  $ticket = simplexml_load_string($zd->get(ZENDESK_TICKETS, array('id' => $ticket_id)))
  if ($zd->result['code'] != 200) {
   /* handle error */
  }
 
  /* get some fields from the ticket */
  $ticket_priority = $ticket->{'priority-id'};
  $ticket_priority = (int) $ticket_priority;
  $created_at = $ticket->{'created-at'};
  $age = (int) ((time() - strtotime((String) $created_at[0])) / 60 / 60 / 24);

  /* get the importance of the customer from our internal customer database */
  $customer_priority = ...

  $score = $customer_priority + min($age, MAX_AGE) / MAX_AGE * MAX_SCORE + $ticket_priority / MAX_TICKET_PRIORITY * MAX_SCORE;
  $zd->update(ZENDESK_TICKETS, array('id' => $ticket_id, 'details' => array(
    'ticket-field-entries' => array(
      array('ticket-field-id' => 20037037, 'value' => $score),
    ),
  )));
  if ($zd->result['code'] != 200) {
    /* handle error */
  }

As you can see the score is based on the weighted sum of the importance of the customer ($customer_priority), the age of the ticket and the priority.

In order to intialize the scores you can update all tickets:

  /* Zendesk returns only 15 results per search result page so call this in a loop */ 
  $page = 1;
  do {
    $tickets = simplexml_load_string($zd->get(ZENDESK_SEARCH, array('query' => array('query' => 'status<solved', 'page' => $page))));
    if ($zd->result['code'] != 200) {
     /* handle error */
    }
    $num_tickets = $tickets['count'];
    foreach ($tickets->record as $ticket) {
      $ticket_id = $ticket->{'nice-id'};
      /* set the score using the code from above */
      set_score($ticket_id);
    }
  } while ($page++ * TICKETS_PER_PAGE < $num_tickets);

This approach works like a charm and allows us to work on tickets from top to bottom. Urgent problems and important customers get a fast response time, and  factoring in the ticket age also means that tickets will bubble to the top as they get older even if they are not that important.

entries.title: CC'ing Recipients to Your Tickets (and Allowing Them to Butt In)
entries.body:
Cc'ing is disabled by default but can be enabled under SETTINGS / Tickets ("Enable CCs on tickets")

When an end-user creates a ticket via email and Cc's other recipients in that email, the Cc recipients will receive email notifications on future updates to the ticket. Furthermore the Cc recipients will be able to add comments to the ticket conversation either by replying to the email notification or using the self-service pages.


Note:

  • An end-user can add Cc recipients via email any time during a ticket's lifetime.
  • Only agents can delete Cc recipients once they're added.
  • When Cc'ing unknown end-users in an open help desk via email, the new users will be created automatically IF users are not required to register to access your zendesk (see "Account" => "User admission")
  • When a ticket is created by email, Zendesk evaluates all other recipients in that email (both To: and Cc: recipients) and makes them cc recipients on future ticket updates.
  • A maximum of 8 Cc's are allowed - this to prevent spam scenarios.

 

Cc Recipents are notified when they are on the cc list and

  • A ticket update contains a comment 
  • The cc recipient is not notified by any trigger 
  • The cc recipient is not author of the comment
  • The cc recipient is not part of an originating email Cc line. This eliminates Cc recipients receiving multiple identical updates

Agent recipients receive all updates. End-user recipients only receive public updates.

 

Settings

 

When enabled the feature configuration sports several settings:

You can select that only agents can add cc's. This means that cc's on emails from users will never be added to the ticket

The Cc black list is implemented to prevent e.g. forwarded support addresses to be included as cc recipients. If you forward your support mail from an address in your own domain to anything@account.zendesk.com, you don't want the original address to occur as Cc recipient. 

The Cc email text is the text snippet that is being included in all emails to Cc recipients.

entries.title: Widgets
entries.body:
Zendesk widgets are small customizable pieces of content you can include in your help desk. This could be simple text guiding the users of your help desk or more advanced widgets that integrate with other web services. Widgets are displayed in the sky blue boxes on the right side of your help desk screen.

Zendesk provides a number of ready made widgets that can easily be added to your help desk, as well a custom widgets for more advanced users.

When configuring a widget you can specify who the widget will be available to. You have the option to specify "anyone", "agents" and "logged in end-users". Use this feature to restrict the access to your widgets.

Placing Widgets in Your Pages

Once you have configured a widget, you need to navigate to the page where you want the widget to appear and click the "Edit widgets on this page" link below the sky blue widget boxes on the right:

There are two exceptions to this; The CSS widget and JavaScript widget. These two widget types are placed on all pages if the user has access to the widget according to the widgets availability.

Display Information in Widgets

The simplest form of widget is a widget with static plain text. To create this form of widget, simple add a custom widget and enter some plain text into the content area.

Zendesk also provides a Text widget that can be used to fade between different texts in the widget.

Modifying Colors

If you want to modify the colors or layout of your help desk you can use the CSS widget type. With this you can insert any CSS. If you wanted to change the color of headings, you cold create a CSS widget with this content:

h1, h2, h3 {
   background-color: #FF0000;
}

Modifying Content

You can also change the content of your help desk by creating a JavaScript widget that modifies the HTML document. If you wanted to add a tab to the tab bar with a link to google, you could create a JavaScript widget with the content:

Event.observe(window, 'load', function() {
   $$('#top-menu #green')[0].insert('<li class="main"><a class="tab" href="http://google.com">Google</a></li>');
});

If you wanted to change the name of your help desk in the header, you could create a JavaScript widget with the content:

Event.observe(window, 'load', function() {
   $('table_header').down('a').update('Our Fantastic Help Desk')
});

Advanced Widgets

If you have not been scared away by the above JavaScript widget, you probably want to check out our Widget API Documentation for more information on creating advanced widgets.

entries.title: What's The Score?
entries.body:
Every ticket in your Zendesk help desk is scored between 0 and 100. The score is an objective value for which tickets you need to address first. The higher the score the more urgent/important the ticket is. The score is a relative value. So even though you only have two working tickets in your help desk, and both of them are pretty tedious, they can still score 100.

When calculating the score we consider a number of factors: How old is the ticket, how well has it been qualified and is somebody working on it. A ticket that hasn’t been qualified at all will typically score high, encouraging your agents to inspect and assign tickets as they come in. Ticket that has been lying around for a long time will score high, incidents will score higher than questions, and of course will urgent priority tickets score higher than lower priority tickets.

An important consideration is that a ticket that has been lying around for a while unqualified easily can score higher than an urgent priority incident. Although the urgent incident undoubtedly is important, it has been qualified and somebody has been assigned to it. Whereas the unqualified ticket potentially can be much more important. You don’t know until somebody has qualified it.

We now colorcode the score in ticket views which hopefully will strengthen their value in day-to-day operations.

entries.title: End User Ticket Count widget
entries.body:
This is a custom widget that can placed in the sidebar to let the user know how many requests they have open and solved. For the first five open or pending  requests you will see the subject line and the first 200 character of the description with a direct link to the request. 

 

For the code make sure you have edited your CSS to display the results the way you want. 

 

//Zendesk end user ticket count widget

<div id="tikcetfeedContent">
	
</div>
<script type="javascript">
	 
$j(document).ready(function() {


truncate = function(text, length, ellipsis) {    

    // Set length and ellipsis to defaults if not defined
    if (typeof length == 'undefined') var length = 100;
    if (typeof ellipsis == 'undefined') var ellipsis = '...';

    // Return if the text is already lower than the cutoff
    if (text.length < length) return text;

    // Otherwise, check if the last character is a space.
    // If not, keep counting down from the last character
    // until we find a character that is a space
    for (var i = length-1; text.charAt(i) != ' '; i--) {
        length--;
    }

    // The for() loop ends when it finds a space, and the length var
    // has been updated so it doesn't cut in the middle of a word.
    return text.substr(0, length) + ellipsis;
}
	 

//used to start the queue to ensure the open request appear before the solved requests	
var para = $j("div#top-menu");	

//get the open requests 
para.queue("testQueue", function(next){$j.get('/requests.xml', function(d) {
           var countopen = $j(d).find('ticket').parent().attr('count');
           if(!countopen){countopen = 0;}
           //makes a linkt to all open tickets 
           $j('#tikcetfeedContent').append("<h2><em class=\"rssdate\"><a href=\"/requests\">Open Tickets: " + countopen + "<\/a><\/em><\/h2><br>");
		
		$j(d).find('ticket').each(function(index) {

			//name the current found item this for this particular loop run
			var $item = $j(this);
			// grab the ticket subject
			var title = $item.find('subject').text();

			// grab the tickets ID
			var link = $item.find('nice-id').text();
			// next, the description the second value sets the number of characters to display the 3rd value is what you want the ellipse to be 
                        var description = truncate($item.find('description').text(), 200, '...');
			
			// now create a var 'html' to store the markup we're using to output the feed to the browser window
			var html = "<div class=\"rssentry\"><h2 class=\"rsspostTitle\">" + title + "<\/h2>";
			html += "<p class=\"rssdescription\">" + description + "</p>";
			html += "<a href=\"/requests/" + link + "\" target=\"_blank\">Read More >><\/a><\/div>";

			//put that feed content on the screen!
			$j('#tikcetfeedContent').append(html);

                        // Set the number of items you want displayed remember the count starts at zero this is set to 5
                        if(index > 3) {return false;}  

		});
	});
      next();
  });

//setting a delay to ensure that the ticket call completes before the current user call
    para.delay( 500, "testQueue" );

//get the solved ticket count only 
 para.queue("testQueue", function(next) {$j.get('/requests.xml?filter=solved', function(solved) {
         var countSolved = $j(solved).find('ticket').parent().attr('count');
          if(!countSolved){countSolved = 0;}
    //makes a link to the solved request view 
	$j('#tikcetfeedContent').append("<p><h2><em class=\"rssdate\"><a href=\"/requests?filter=solved\">Solved Tickets: " + countSolved + "<\/a><\/em><\/h2><br></p>");
	
		
	});
     next();
    });
    para.dequeue( "testQueue" );
 });

</script>

entries.title: How to add a message preventing you from commenting under an assumed identity
entries.body:
Assuming the identity of another user is great! However, you might forget that you are assumed (either as a coworker or as a customer) and post a comment on a ticket. Needless to say, this confuses customers and also serves to invalidate the sanctity of the "audit trail" in Zendesk. For example, I could assume the role of a customer and say "I authorize you to bill me for $1000 extra" in a ticket. The audit trail would show the customer as posting the message, with no indication that it was really an admin assumed as a customer.

Anyways, we wrote some javascript to detect if you are under an assumed identity and warn you if you try to comment:

 

$j(function ($) {

    var isAssumed = ($('a[href="/users/revert"]').length) ? true : false;

    var confirmed = false;

 

    if (isAssumed) $('#comment_value').blur();

 

    $('#comment_value').focusin(function () {

        if (confirmed || !isAssumed) return;

        var idName = $('#top-right-name').text();

        var warning =  "You are editing as " + idName + ". Are you sure you want to continue? \n\nHit \"Cancel\" to revert identity or \"OK\" to post as " + idName + ".";

        if (!confirm(warning)) {

            window.location.href="/users/revert";

            $(this).blur();

        }

        confirmed = true;

    });

});

Enjoy!

entries.title: Liquidplanner integration
entries.body:
We use Liquidplanner at work as our project management tool http://bit.ly/6wA3N1

We have set up Zendesk to add tasks to an "inbox" folder in Liquidplanner automatically by using an email target and trigger. Incidents/problems/questions are ignored as they are likely to be quick jobs requiring immediate action, rather than needing to be scheduled in.

From the inbox it is easy to then drag the added tasks to a project folder and assign an estimated duration. This is proving to be really useful.

The Zendesk ticket assignee is automatically set as the task owner in Liquidplanner. Here's how:

 

  1. Create folder in Liquidplanner and call it Inbox
  2. Right-click on the folder and select Collaboration --> Get this folder's email address. You will be presented with a unique email address for that folder.
  3. Make sure your Liquidplanner email integration security is set to low to allow incoming emails from an unregistered email address. Go to Settings --> Email Integration and set the Inbound Emails setting to Low Security.
  4. In Zendesk go to Account --> Targets and add an Email Target
  5. Call it e.g. Liquidplanner and enter the email address obtained in step 2 above
  6. In the Subject field I have entered {{ticket.title}} (#{{ticket.id}}),{{ticket.assignee.first_name}}. This is Liquidplanner notation: first the task title and then the task owner, separated by a comma. I have set Liquidplanner up so the user's name reflects the first name of the Zendesk account name. Save the target.
  7. Then add a trigger in Manage --> Triggers and Email Notifications. See the attached screenshot for our setup but you can tune this to your needs. By adding the due date, requester name and project code to the task description we can easily refer to them in Liquidplanner. The addition of the "lp" tag ensures that each task is only written to Liquidplanner once. I'm sure there are other ways of doing this.

Let me know what you think.

entries.title: Why GPS loves Zendesk, and why everyone else should too
entries.body:
I love working with technology that likes to work with others.  In the end that makes my (and my client's) life so much easier.  Originally our company had started with freshbooks as our ticketing system.  But since they are amazing at invoices, (and not so much ticket systems) we quickly looked elsewhere.

We had several ventures that were opening up, so we decided to go with Salesforce, and I did some pretty amazing coding to make a ticket system that could handle eight different TYPES of tickets ~ and was very VERY proud of myself until I realized that my clients couldn't interact, my contractors were so expensive to add to the service, and they found it difficult to remember where everything was.  Regardless of that, we persevered.

THEN, like MAGIC, I found zendesk.

We have a ton of customizations that I've done, that I wanted to share, because I adore you guys.

  1. Tickets that come in from specific clients with (for instance) Priority:1 in the email, automatically become urgent and are color coded in the system.  Each type of priority has a different color / designation.
  2. We have implemented using Google Calendar and Google Docs ~ making our scheduling and associated documents easy to manage in multiple locations.
  3. We implemented the time tracking widget for freshbooks (has cut 4 hours a month off of our billing, since the information from each ticket is automatically tracked now.
  4. We setup printing for three different layouts for different types of jobs.  Click a button, and Voila ~ tickets for signing, giving to contractors for site jobs, etc.
  5. We added banners for products / services that we recommend for our clients.
  6. We added in links to other management areas that we have, and use on a regular basis, so that our contractors don't have to try to remember all the tools we use :)
  7. Implemented a route planning widget that allows us to map and view from two specific locations to any address.  We then can track that information on each of our on-site type tickets.
  8. Implemented a contractor agreement that pulls information about jobs directly from the tickets and creates a sign-able contract including contractor rates / mileage rates, and a signature for each on-site job.
  9. I'm putting some screen shots up to show how we have used your amazing ticket system!

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU

I am still adding things to our Zendesk, but we have only been using it officially since March, and it is a HUGE hit.

entries.title: They Love It
entries.body:
A short history of how I launched Zendesk. Or what I call "How Zendesk Convinced My Coworkers We Actually Have a Help Desk". 

  • Had a help desk application. Web based. I hosted it. Nobody used it. Nobody. Ever. Used. It.  
  • Decided to walk around and find out what was up. 
  • User reaction can be summed up in three categories: (1) "What help desk?" (2) "I hate it, I don't use it" (3) "Who are you again?"
  • Being a seasoned and highly trained I.T. professional and through hours of in-depth analysis and self-reflection I determined that people were not using my help desk because they hated it. (Yea, deep, I know.)
  • Furthermore, my extensive experience told me to get a new help desk application. Yea, I'm that good. ;-)
  • I started my search. I had two criteria - I would not host my next application, it would be simple, customizable and beautiful. Okay, that is more than two. Whatever.   
  • Looked at everything. Demoed a lot apps. There are a lot of really bad help desk applications out there. I will not call out my old application. You know who you are.  
  • It was painful. 
  • Found Zendesk. Simple to use. Looks great. In the cloud. Nice. 
  • Signed up. Customized it. 
  • Beta tested it internally. Reaction was, "That is cool!" 
  • "You mean the help desk is...cool?" I said. Yes, they did. 
  • Launched it. 
  • Threw a party. 
  • Bribed users with food. Told them if they opened a ticket asking for food they could come and get some. 
  • An amazing thing happen. My coworkers did it...without help. 
  • And they ate my food. That part was not so amazing.  
  • I am now working on GoodData for Zendesk. Great reporting. In the cloud. Life is good. 

Reaction is now. "It's really easy to use", "We love it", "Service is so much better now." And EVERYBODY is using it. First couple of months over 90% of requests came in through Zendesk. (Instead of calling or emailing my department.) 

I now have a help desk. I have metrics. I have happy users and a happy I.T. Manager. (Me.)

Keep up the good work guys.

From a functional perspective our top three requirements were that it must..

  1. be very easy to use for both customers and agents (throughout the ticket work flow, and on the online FAQ/forum areas)
  2. provide integrated email ticket management, FAQs, and forum capability. The key being that help resources would all be searchable in one place - whether they be official FAQs or contributions from the community
  3. have an established, well proven, and well documented API (and in particular a proven model with regard to CRM integration)

The evaluation concluded that Zendesk was clearly the best solution for our needs. In fact it stood out as significantly superior to the competition on not just these three criteria.

Since doing the evaluation we have set up two instances of Zendesk

  1. For a help desk to support the website
  2. For an internal "Change Forum". This instance is strictly private to employees (using a number of white listed email domains)

We are such fans of the Zendesk product, and have received such fantastic support from the Zendesk crew over the last few months that we have decided to share our evaluation criteria with this community. entries.title: Zendesk is just the ticket!  A pantomime with a happy ending...
entries.body:
Yes, that's right!  There is a happy ending after the tale of woe and despair.  If you're a software company that needs to offer customer support and link to your own systems, read on!

Our tale starts with an over-worked programmer, Clive, doubling up as support agent, slaving away on the helpdesk.

 

Opening scene: engineer at helpdesk

A customer rocks up at the helpdesk and is demanding support.  Our unlucky programmer-come-support-engineer looks at the ticket and his heart sinks.  Another customer that can't read, can't search, doesn't know Google from mud, and is in a hurry.  But, ponders Clive, "I don't recognize this e-mail address?"

Clive scurries away and searches his e-mail client for traces of that e-mail address.  No hits.  Hmm.

Clive delves further.  He takes a look at the list of software activations going back ten years.  No hits.  Uh, huh.

Being the super-sleuth that he is, Clive brings up the list of customers as, gee, it's very long now even for this two-bit software company and he surely cannot remember all the customers that splashed their cash.  Still no joy.  Burp!

(Clive decides that living on carbonated energy drinks might need a lifestyle adjustment and wonders if they can be expensed.)

Clive knows that support time is precious, because time taken supporting customers is time away from penning the next cliffhanger instalment of the product that pays the bills.  But outside the Ivory Tower that circumscribes our hero's life, there are bad people, those that would wish to steal time from our hero without paying the troll that guards the bridge over the moat to the tower.  (Did I mention that our hero is shackled to his desk?)

Sweat beading on our hero's brow, he decides that it's time to resovle the are-you-a-paying-customer question by recasting it as a programming exercise...

 

Cut to scene at desk, coding...

Clive tries to learn PHP to edit the source of his bought-in helpdesk.  No joy, PHP is spaghetti, the code is all over the place, there's SQL commands to learn and Linux to conquer, MySQL configuration and masses of other things that our programmer knows nothing to less than nothing about.  Overwhelmed, he admits defeat: it's just impossible for him to stretch his helpdesk to integrate with his license and customer contact information.  This is a blow to our hero--not being able to solve a problem by programming his way out of it when he asked for the title "Software Guru" on his business cards to be inked luminous orange.

Stumbling, he raises a ticket on his helpdesk provider's helpdesk to try to get some information on any integration that he can do.. No reply.  He marks it Urgent.  No reply.  He ups the ante by offering a bounty for a custom integration.  Still no reply.  Drenched in perspiration, he wonders whether his helpdesk provider has gone the way of the dodo leaving him high and dry (read another way, that could be called a result!)

Realisation dawns that he will get nowhere with his current helpdesk and needs a change.  Which is as good as a rest, but then our hero never rests!

 

Cut to The way to enlightenment

Using The Force of Google, Clive researches a replacement.  Lots of helpdesks, way over-specified for a part-time support engineer.  All of them look pretty complex, too many check boxes and too much time-tracking and configuration options for a three-man support team to handle.

Over an egg sandwidh, Clive sends an e-mail to try to get some help with his recently-set-up UserVoice feedback forum.  By return an e-mail arrives with some fetching lime banners that really stand out.  Intrigued by the mail, Clive digs a bit deeper.  Hmm.  Zendesk.  Peering closely at his monitor and dropping crumbs into his keyboard for good measure, Clive browses for this Zendesk thing on the web.  What he finds astounds him.  Wiping the spattered egg mayo from his 30" monitor, his excitement mounts.  Zendesk Custom Widgets.  Oh.  My.  God.

 

Final scene: Clive saved from early heart attack

Yes, with a couple of days coding, Clive and his team integrate the data in their own license and customer lists into Zendesk so that, when somebody pops up at the helpdesk, all information about that user is on hand.  Yes, our intrepid support engineers now have renewed confidence in their replies, safe in the knowledge that the custom panel at the side of the helpdesk has current information on the licenses the user holds, whether he has a support contract, whether he is evaluating, or whether he's one of those bad people that want to siphon the life out of his company.

 

The skinny...

The one feature we needed from a helpdesk was that of identifying support requests from customers that have (in essence) stolen our software and triaging them.  We couldn't do it with our existing helpdesk, and looked overly complex with many other helpdesks.

The custom widget integration is a killer feature of Zendesk.  Simple and effective.  Easy to work with.  Zendesk has an excellent set of features for integration of your own systems.  And it's clean, it's elegant, it's simple, and it's just right!

Because we can integrate what we like into Zendesk, there's no end to what we can do.  Things are amazingly streamlined for us now we have information at hand: no searching, no looking up in other systems, no jumping into the accounting office to find copy invoices...

Our old helpdesk?  Retired but leading an active life.  Zendesk is, by far, the best fit for our company.  Zendesk's own support is excellent (though, to be fair, we do have an outstanding issue that needs to be resolved...)

Am I content with Zendesk?  Yes I am!

All characters appearing in this work are fictitious. Any resemblance to real persons, living or dead, is purely coincidental but not entirely accidental.  No trees were damaged delivering this message, but some electrons were forced to migrate.

entries.title: Well behaved Help Desk - Excellent!
entries.body:
Having worked various service desks in my career, I have used a lot of Help Desk/Ticketing systems. From Bugzilla to Remedy, from Royal Blue's offering to CA-Unicenter's AHD software. I also have been to many mind numbing demos, and shown new wizzy bits'n'bobs that the sales guy's software can do, and I can honestly say, without exception that yes, they do in fact work.... but do I really need all this? Do I really need to spend serious chunks of my life configuring and integrating this system, then re-training my guys to use this piece of software? Are my customers going to use it, and get what they want out of it easily, or do they need to be a techie of geek proportions to even log an issue with us?

Like most people in ICT I guess, I suffer from the 'Hey, did you know, you can do this..?' and promptly go off and do it, never actually stopping and asking the question, 'Yes, I can do this, but should I, what are the benefits to either myself, my team, or indeed my customer?'. Had I known then, what I do now, then maybe I wouldn't have wasted so much of my time and effort with these other bloated applications, when all I really want is an easy way for my customers to interact with us, and get the help and support they need.

But, ZenDesk IS different. It does what it say's it does, with the minimum of fuss and fanfare. With a few tweaks here and there, it can fit in with any corporate scheme - even ours!

Like all evolving software there are always things that you want, or would like, but need? I don't believe there is anything missing from this package that we actually need. With the addition of widgets, and a bit of back end coding of php pages on our own web server, I have even manegd to get our telephony details showing on all agents pages, so they now know who is logged in, available, and what the abandoned rate is. They even know how many calls each of them is fielding, a bonus that proves itself time and again in call centers, with agents competing for that top spot.

I am about at the end of the trial period now, and am definately continuing with this product. For now, just the 5 agents (downer..), but when our existing contracted software runs out, very soon, we're going for the full 25 agent offering. I have already got buy in from the exec, and have another department wanting to use the system internally, so we will probably end up running a couple of instances of this one.

Well done ZenDesk ... I do 'love your helpdesk', and am beginning to love mine too!

M:)
